comments:
This course examines how we as consumers in the "Western" world engage with musical difference largely through the products of the global entertainment industry. The course examines music cultures in contact in a variety of ways-- particularly as traditions in transformation. The purpose of the course is to enable students to become informed and critical consumers of "World Music" by telling a series of stories about particular recordings made with, or using the music of, peoples culturally and geographically distant from the US. 

This course was taught in many sessions by different instructors, but Professor Holtzman’s classes were “not solely based on lectures.” According to students, this course was “taught the right way,” meaning that the course focused more on letting the students learn more rather than merely preparing the students for an exam. The course introduced a lot of different genres of music that students “would not have had experience with otherwise.” The course also enabled students to “think differently – or at least just to think – about music,” “questioning things [they] would not normally question.”

Students stated that Professor Holtzman “really cared about students understanding the material and thinking about it.” He was “exceptional at facilitating course-related discussions and allowing all students to involve themselves.” He was able to create a comfortable environment for students to participate and contribute to the class. According to many, “his passion for the material really came through to students.”

Students described the course as a “great and painless way to fulfill a bunch of general requirements.” The course fulfills the Cross Cultural Analysis and Cultural Diversity in US general requirements, and the Arts & Letters sector. This course was highly recommended for “non-majors wanting a good introduction to international music and the phenomenon of the world music genre.”
